elements.title: Hell Gate Bridge (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in 2005, a mag­a­zine estimated that the Hell Gate Bridge (pictured) could last a thousand years if humans disappeared?

elements.title: A-Channel (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that an Edmonton politician began mouthing his words when he saw a cameraman for A-Channel walk in, mocking the frequent audio difficulties on its newscasts?

elements.title: Wayne Cook (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Wayne Cook tied the UCLA single-game record for touchdown passes in consecutive weeks en route to their first Rose Bowl in eight years?

elements.title: Scott Tower (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Scott Tower was built in 1940 as part of a project to create Holyoke, Massachusetts' "own version of New York City's Central Park"?

elements.title: Randy Travis (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that, after Randy Travis lost most of his singing ability to a stroke in 2013, James Dupré has sung his songs for him in concert?

elements.title: Video Seven (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Video Seven released the first VGA video card with video RAM?

elements.title: Émile Gilliéron (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Émile Gilliéron was accused of making Minoan frescoes look like Vogue models?

elements.title: a group of death row inmates filed a lawsuit (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a group of death row inmates filed a lawsuit when the U.S. government refused to confiscate their states' lethal injection drugs?

elements.title: Jourdan Saunders (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that slave trader Jourdan Saunders greatly profited from a Louisiana law banning slave trading?
